executive_summary: Demand for movie theaters has been on a consistent dip thanks to intense competition from online streaming platforms. The industry experienced its most significant drop in performance amid the outbreak of COVID-19, which fueled at-home viewership. The pandemic created substantial disruptions for the industry as theatres temporarily closed and audiences stayed home, which resulted in industry revenue plummeting 73.2% in 2020. Although the industry experienced robust growth in 2021 and 2022 as restrictions eased and audiences returned, revenue has yet to return to its pre-pandemic total. Revenue has fallen at a CAGR of 6.1% to $15.3 billion through the end of 2024. Profitability has returned following pandemic lows thanks to theatres implementing monthly subscription programs and offering premium concessions, but overall profit remains depressed from where it was in 2019.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Movie Theaters Were Devastated by COVID-19
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In 2020, social distancing restrictions aimed at curbing the spread of COVID-19 forced movie theaters to close during their busiest time, the summer blockbuster season. Even when movie theaters were eventually allowed to reopen, limited-capacity seating prevented revenue growth that year. Pent-up demand brought moviegoers back to the theater in 2021, contributing to a massive period of growth that extended into 2022. Growth has since returned to typical marginal rates in 2024, when revenue will hike 1.3%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Drop in Disposable Income Amid Inflation
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Movie theaters rely on consumers having enough extra spending money to justify going out and making discretionary purchases, like movie theater tickets and concessions. Widespread inflation in 2022 pushed grocery store and energy bills upwards dramatically, leading to a drop in disposable income. Dropping per capita, disposable income puts pressure on movie theaters to keep their prices low, but many movie theaters can't drop their prices because of their already cumbersome revenue-generation challenges.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Tough Competition Has Pummeled Movie Theaters
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A growing reliance on streaming services to see popular movies has dramatically reduced demand for box office tickets. Theaters have been partially left out of the loop as production companies increasingly send their films directly to their streaming services at a premium upcharge.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Revenue Will Finally Return To Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the industry recovers from the setback of COVID-19 and inflationary pressure begins to ease, revenue will climb as more and more people who stopped attending movies return to the box office.

Rising per capita disposable income is poised to help drive consumer spending on movie theater admissions, especially for premium-priced tickets, like IMAX and 3D, along with concessions items. Consumer confidence will also rebound from previous drops, encouraging consumers to spend more time on recreational activities and make more discretionary purchases, like tickets to a new movie.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Streaming Service Subscriptions Will Constrain Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The trend toward streaming services and on-demand at-home entertainment has been rapidly accelerated by COVID-19 and a lessened reliance on movie theaters to see the current big movie will continue to subdue revenue growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: SHRINKING THEATER-ONLY WINDOWS WILL BRING DOWN REVENUE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Theatrical release windows still give movie theaters a few months of protection, but a shrinking time window will damage box office sales even more.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THEATERS MAKE ADJUSTMENTS TO ADAPT TO NEW CONDITIONS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Theaters will raise ticket and concession prices to compensate for dampened attendance. Still, the industry's elasticity of demand will make this a more than imperfect solution to its challenges. Some theaters are exploring dynamic seating arrangements that adjust based on factors like ticket sales, seat preferences and group sizes, optimizing the seating layout to maximize occupancy and revenue while ensuring a comfortable viewing experience for patrons.

industry_definition: This industry comprises businesses that primarily show movies. It includes cinemas, drive-in and outdoor movie theaters and film festival exhibitors.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - increasing

key_trends: Popular films attract audience members, so movie theaters must ensure they have the rights to the season's biggest hit. Movie theaters must also compete with projects released directly to streaming services that have taken away the exclusivity of movie theaters.
Many consumers are happy to wait a few months for a popular film to come out on Netflix or HBO Max.
Major chains control much of the market, but small theaters find their niche.
While AMC, Cinemark and Cineworld dominate over half of the market, independents thrive by offering unique experiences and catering to community interests.
COVID-19 hit movie theaters hard, but they're bouncing back.
Despite crushing losses in 2020, innovative strategies and pent-up demand have driven a significant recovery, though challenges like inflation and streaming competition persist.
Shorter theatrical release windows will damage revenue.
Vertically integrated production studios increasingly turn to streaming to avoid piracy and boost revenue for other businesses under their ownership.
Movie theaters are evolving to offer more than just films.
From luxury seating to live events and in-theater dining, cinemas are transforming into multi-experience venues to entice audiences away from their couches and back to the big screen.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumers aged 17 and younger account for a similar share of revenue proportional to their share of the population. This group has more leisure time to indulge in movies and blockbusters usually target them.
Young adults within this bracket view movies as an affordable form of entertainment and a social event but are increasingly turning to streaming services due to their convenience.

Consumers in this age group often have more disposable income, which better enables them to see a new movie. This segment tends to initiate family-related movie-going. They are frequent moviegoers, often seeing a movie once a month or more.

A lack of pressure to keep up with new movies and pop culture decreases the frequency at which older adults go to the movies. The elderly have not grown up with technology and are less connected to the primary marketing strategies for movies, so they are often unaware of new films.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes admissions to 3D, drive-in and IMAX movie showings of domestic and foreign films. Box office ticket sales involve the revenue generated from movie viewings at theatres and ticket sales from physical and online platforms.

Candy, popcorn, soda and other snack item sales through concession stands and vending machines account for over one-quarter of revenue. Many theaters have rolled out full-service, dine-in options that serve a variety of entrees, and the sale of alcoholic beverages has become increasingly popular.
Advertising, including on-screen previews and physical displays, generates a small share of revenue. Movies aimed at a younger audience rely, especially, on advertising.
Arcade games, theater rentals, parking lots for special events, fees from customer loyalty programs and gift card sales also make up a small share of revenue.

tier_1_suppliers: Snack Food Production in the US
Soft Drink, Baked Goods & Other Grocery Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Movie & Video Distribution in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Copier & Optical Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Electric Power Transmission in the US
tier_2_buyers: Movie & Video Production in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: As a leisure activity, movie attendance relies on household disposable income levels, which, in turn, are affected by the employment rate, tax rates and the general state of the economy. When disposable income levels rise, people are more able and willing to spend on discretionary items, driving up ticket and concession sales. Trips to the movies are reduced when disposable income falls.

business_locations.location_description: More people mean more moviegoers, and the Southeast is the most populous region in the US. It contains the most movie theaters, corresponding to its share of the total population.

Higher disposable income and leisure time in this region have permitted more consumers to see movies. California's historical connection to film contributes greatly to the prominence of movie theaters in the region. The West is a hotbed for film culture and movie critics, with Hollywood epitomizing this, promoting movie theaters.
Regions with large cities have a more concentrated population that is better served by fewer big movie theaters, leading to areas such as the Great Lakes having fewer but larger theaters.
Regions with large cities have a more concentrated population that is better served by fewer big movie theaters, leading to areas such as the Mid-Atlantic having fewer but larger theaters.
More sparse regions, such as the Rocky Mountains, require more movie theaters to service the moviegoing needs of the region's dispersed consumers.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Like many entertainment industries, movie theaters experienced severe revenue drops during the onset of COVID-19 in 2020. Stay-at-home orders and mandatory shutdowns closed operations on a massive scale to uphold social distancing measures.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Seating capacity allowed some theaters to reopen the ticket booth
regulations_points.regulation_description: Seating capacity allowed some theaters to reopen the ticket booth, but reduced admissions sales were brutal for movie theaters' profit.
The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990 requires movie theaters to operate facilities that cater to those with disabilities.
Theaters must adhere to the Motion Picture Association's film rating system, ensuring that age-inappropriate content is not viewed by underage audiences.
Movie theaters must obtain proper licensing to publicly screen films. This involves negotiating rights and paying fees to the film's distributors or studios.
Theaters that sell food and beverages must comply with local and state licensing laws, including obtaining the necessary permits for operation.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Theaters can now be vertically integrated
regulations_points.regulation_description: A federal judge's decision in 2020 reversed the long-held industry standard and allowed film studios to own and operate movie theaters and vice versa.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Movie theater start-ups need expensive legal licensing to show popular films that bring in crowds.
It's incredibly expensive to purchase screens, digital projectors, audio systems and lease the massive buildings required for movie theaters.

basis_points.basis_description: Movie theaters must ensure they have the rights to the season's biggest hit films to attract audiences.
Movie theaters face competition from projects released directly to streaming platforms.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Major chains like AMC, Cinemark and Cineworld control more than half of the market through acquisitions.
Geographic film licensing zones provide a strong advantage to large establishments.
Diverse consumer preferences allow independent theaters and smaller chains to thrive.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Licensing Fees Pose a Challenge to Theaters
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: A significant part of a movie theatre's expenditure is the licensing or renting of a film from distributors such as Warner Media LLC or Disney.
Labor is a key operational cost within the industry.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Low-wage employees are a necessity for cleaning the theatres and operating concession stands.
Capital investments include screens and projection systems.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Movie theaters typically experience low revenue volatility, but restrictions rolled out during the COVID-19 pandemic dropped revenue by nearly three-quarters in 2020.
A movie ticket is considerably cheaper than a ticket to a sporting event or concert.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Revenue Flows With The Hype For New Movies
volatility_points.volatility_description: Theaters get most of their revenue from admissions.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Film used to be the standard for showing motion pictures but has largely been replaced by digital projectors.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Digital projection has enabled the creation of 3D viewing technologies
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Digital projection has enabled the creation of 3D viewing technologies.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: MONTHLY SUBSCRIPTION MODELS ENSURE CUSTOMER LOYALTY
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Monthly subscription models make moviegoing more accessible.

FAQs.question: How have changes in consumers' electronic usage habits changed your operations?
FAQs.answer: As more people use a variety of electronic devices to view movies, admissions have declined.

FAQs.question: How does your company promote its movies and offerings?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators rely significantly on the hype surrounding new movie releases.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to rising wages in recent years? Has it had a noticeable effect on your bottom line?
FAQs.answer: Several states have increased their minimum wage during the period.

FAQs.question: Is your company strategically located in a beneficial region?
FAQs.answer: Establishments located in urban areas typically generate higher revenue.

FAQs.question: Does your company plan to invest or increase investments in 3D movie technology over the next several years?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators have been able to capitalize on the growing popularity of 3D movies.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology?
FAQs.answer: Operators have been investing in 3D theaters, seating upgrades, and full-service dining operations.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of new regulations like FCC policy changes?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators can look to industry organizations for industry news.

FAQs.question: Are there any regulations in place that currently benefit your company?
FAQs.answer: The theatrical release window benefits industry operators.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors' profit?
FAQs.answer: Profit can vary between operators depending on the level of concessions.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects on the horizon that will require capital financing?
FAQs.answer: Many theaters are engaging in upgrades to projection systems and seating areas.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators need to adopt digital projection systems.

FAQs.question: What portion of your staff are part-time?
FAQs.answer: Movie theaters must have access to a steady stream of young casual employees.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets?
FAQs.answer: It is important to identify key local market segments for movies.

FAQs.question: What strategies does your company have in place that aim to compete with streaming services?
FAQs.answer: With the rapid rise in broadband connection numbers, more consumers are using the internet.

FAQs.question: What technological investments has your company made lately?
FAQs.answer: As movie theaters continue to switch to digital and 3D projection systems.
